ygData.subject: Re: [neat] Writing NEAT and XOR
ygData.msgSnippet: First thing I remember was that the problem was easier to solve with a steeper gain on the sigmoid activation function.  And weight caps were helpful, too. On

First thing I remember was that the problem was easier to solve with a
steeper gain on the sigmoid activation function.  And weight caps were
helpful, too.


On Thu, 09 Sep 2004 22:33:14 -0000, Kenneth Stanley
<kstanley@...> wrote:
> A number of you have successfully written your own versions of NEAT,
> and most people who did so started out testing with XOR.  Since XOR
> has traditionally been the first test, most bugs or problems end up
> being exposed and fixed during XOR.  For those of you who have been
> through this process, can you comment briefly on what you remember
> about how the problems you encountered that initially stopped you
> from solving XOR?  For example, was it weight mutation parameters
> being too high/low, problems with the speciation setup, etc...?  I
> would like to compile people's experiences with this and put it in
> the FAQ since it seems to inevitably come up whenever someone tries
> to write their own version of NEAT, and it would be great if we
> could prevent people from having to go through the same trial and
> error process each time by having a record of the usual problems
> that came up.  Thanks very much, I appreciate any recollections :)
> 
> (For those who don't remember what the problem was with their XOR,
> usually it was manifested as hitting a plateau level and not being
> able to get over it.  Then usually you fixed a few things and
> suddenly NEAT could easily cross the plateau.)
> 
> ken
